body: Hello, there are no known bugs that may lead to that AFAIK, so may be an HW failure or a new unknown Redis bug. There are no hints in the stack trace unfortunately. Please could you check if it happens again and post other crash reports? If they all happen at random locations it could be lack of stability of the hardware. Please also could you check with your VM provider if they are using error corrected memory or not?
Also could be useful to have the original redis server binary. You may send it to antirez at g-mail citing the issue number in the subject. Thanks.
The `0a0a0a0a0a0a0a0a` in the stack looks suspicious. Like if it was crashed on purpose testing some kind of buffer overflow.
Now we log the offending address on SIGSEGV crashes: https://github.com/antirez/redis/commit/6db8e8569d7f41fc4450ceef7b7f91819829d4ca
can you post your binary executable file? so that we can see what instruction lies at 0x4233a9 and what it tries to access.

Will report here if this happens again.
PFA redis bin file.
[redis-server.zip](https://github.com/antirez/redis/files/64107/redis-server.zip)
@rajatflipkart do you still have the full log? maybe there's something useful printed just before the crash report? please upload if you have it.

@oranagra @antirez Is this fixed ? Would I have to rebuild redis from source ?
Is there any temporary fix to this issue. e.g. can I prevent the crash from this issue by making some config change?

yeah, this is most likely fixed now (unless there's another bug we didn't spot there).
I don't think there's any way to avoid this bug, but on the other hand, it seems VERY rare so i doubt you'll see it again.
on the other hand, you'll benefit a lot by upgrading to a more recent version due to other bug fixes.

+1 to Oran reasoning. Very rare, if you see it again in a short timeframe maybe is a different bug. However I'm releasing 2.8 and 3.0 new patchlevels in a matter of days, with this fix. I can't do it today because there are pending things in order to release 3.0.6.

You can either use the latest commit of the `2.8` branch if you want to be sure this bug is fixed in your environment, or also just apply commit e0b7388 in your current tree.

Or wait a few days and install the new 2.8 or 3.0 releases.
